required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Prospective Evaluation of CT Guided Ablation of Cardiac Ganglionated Plexi
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Evaluation of Computed Tomography Guided Ablation of Cardiac Ganglionated Plexi in Patients With Atrial Fibrillation

brief_summary.textblock: Despite progress made in treating atrial fibrillation with catheter ablation, outcomes remain suboptimal with pulmonary vein isolation alone. Ablation of ganglionated plexi (GP) has been shown to be beneficial in patients with atrial fibrillation although optimal strategies of localization of these regions have yet to be determined. The investigators aim to develop a novel strategy of CT guided GP localization to guide ablation in patients with atrial fibrillation. The investigators also aim to clarify the network of innervation between GP to clarify the optimal ablation strategy. This is an observational, single-center study evaluating feasibility and efficacy of CT and high frequency stimulation (HFS) guided GP mapping and ablation in patients with AF undergoing catheter ablation with pulmonary vein isolation. Patients will undergo HFS and CT guided mapping of GPs followed by allocation into one of 8 different GP ablation approaches in a non-randomized fashion.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation between HFS (high frequency signals) and CT identified epicardial adipose tissue.
primary_outcome.description: Correlation will be defined by sites being found within 3 pixels (0.625x3=1.875mm).

secondary_outcome.description: Elimination of local of HFS response following GP ablation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: This will be assessed during the procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Elimination of global vagal response to non-invasive tragal stimulation

secondary_outcome.measure: Ablation site changes - amplitude of signals
secondary_outcome.time_frame: This will be assessed during the procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Characterization of amplitude signals at sites with HFS responses and successful HFS elimination

secondary_outcome.measure: Ablation site changes - duration of signals
secondary_outcome.time_frame: This will be assessed during the procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Characterization of duration of signals at sites with HFS responses and successful HFS elimination

secondary_outcome.measure: Ablation site changes - fractionation of signals
secondary_outcome.time_frame: This will be assessed during the procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Characterization of fractionation of signals at sites with HFS responses and successful HFS elimination

arm_group.description: All patients undergoing ablation with undergo pre-procedural CT as well as HFS mapping and ablation of GPs.

intervention.intervention_name: Ganglionated Plexi mapping and ablation using Natus Cortical Stimulator and standard ablation catheters
intervention.description: Ganglionated plexi will be mapped using high frequency stimulation with standard ablation catheters attached to a Natus Cortical Stimulator for high frequency stimulation. Vagal innervation to the heart will be assessed with non-invasive Parasym tragal stimulation.
intervention.other_name: Vagal stimulation using Parasym tragal stimulator

study_pop.textblock: Adult patients with atrial fibrillation planned to undergo catheter ablation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Provision of signed and dated informed consent form
2. Stated willingness to comply with all study procedures and availability for the duration of the study
3. Male or female, aged 18 years
4. History of AF with plan to undergo catheter ablation
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Contraindication or unwillingness to undergo CT imaging or catheter ablation.
2. Pregnancy or lactation

facility.name: Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania
Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania

patient_data.ipd_description: No individual participant data will be shared with other researchers.
